Dust Degradation Report

DDR-0047: Projected Bit Rot Timeline for JPEG2000 Archives, 2025–2060

By 2032, approximately 18% of JPEG2000 files stored on consumer-grade SSDs will exhibit partial header corruption due to charge leakage in NAND cells exposed to ambient temperature variance exceeding manufacturer tolerances. This is not a defect. This is physics reminding you that it does not care about your wedding photos.

Our longitudinal study of 4,200 personal archives (donated posthumously; we are legally required to say "donated") indicates that the median user discovers file corruption 6.3 years after the point of no return. By then, the original camera is in a landfill in Accra, the editing software has been acqui-hired into oblivion, and the backup drive is in a box labeled "MISC — DO NOT THROW AWAY" that someone will absolutely throw away.

We recommend immediate cold-storage migration to M-DISC or archival-grade tape. We also recommend accepting that you will not do this. The projected survival rate for unattended JPEG2000 archives by 2060 is 11%. The projected survival rate for your memory of what those photos contained is lower.

The Digital Antiquities Act

OFFICIAL
SEAL
D.A.A.
View: Chronos Corp. Approved Version

Preamble

We, the undersigned archivists, data hoarders, and sentimentalists, do hereby declare that the systematic abandonment of digital artifacts by corporate entities constitutes a cultural crime of staggering indifference. We have watched platforms evaporate. We have seen file formats euthanized. We are tired of being told to "export your data" forty-eight hours before the servers go dark.

Article I: On the Right to Continued Existence of Data

Every file created in good faith — every half-finished novel, every blurry photograph, every spreadsheet of dubious accounting — possesses an inherent right to persist beyond the business cycle of the platform that hosted it. A sunset is a natural phenomenon. A "sunsetting" is a euphemism for arson.

Article II: On the Criminality of Planned Obsolescence

The deliberate engineering of format incompatibility shall be recognized as an act of cultural vandalism equivalent to burning a library, except worse, because at least a fire is honest about what it's doing. Proprietary codecs are hostage situations. DRM is a padlock on a coffin.

Article III: On the Inalienable Right of a .bmp File to Exist

The .bmp format, widely derided as "inefficient" and "obsolete," has outlasted three major social networks, two operating systems, and one civilizational attention span. We demand its recognition as a protected cultural heritage format. It is honest. It is enormous. It does not compress your memories to save shareholders four cents per gigabyte.

Article IV: On the Obligation to Grieve

When a platform dies, there shall be a mandatory period of digital mourning. No executive shall be permitted to describe the destruction of user data as "an exciting new chapter" without first reading aloud the filenames of everything they deleted. All of them. Alphabetically.

"We are not joking. We are also joking." —E.T.
"We are not joking. We are also joking." —E.T.

flux_capacitor_99 2044-09-14 02:31 UTC
Finally got my Pentium III rig emulated cleanly in QEMU 9.2 on Debian 14 (kernel 6.8.41-lts). Key was disabling ACPI and forcing ISA sound emulation for the SB16. Can now open .wri files from a 1997 Compaq Presario backup. The file was a letter my mom never sent. I closed the emulator.
archival_jane VERIFIED 2044-11-02 18:47 UTC
DOSBox-X build 2044.08 + custom VESA patch for 1024×768×16bpp. Running Windows 3.11 with Paintbrush to view .pcx files from a BBS archive (1994, telecity.freeserve.co.uk/~archive). The colors are wrong but they were probably wrong then too. Tested on 847 files — 91.3% render. The other 8.7% are gone.
null_island 2045-01-19 09:12 UTC
Managed to boot a Sun Ultra 5 image under Solaris 9 in a nested VM (KVM → Bhyve → Solaris zone). Only needed it to run one StarOffice 5.2 install to open a .sdw file. The document was 340 words. A resignation letter, dated 2001. It took me six weeks to build this rig. Worth it.

Patron Artifact of the Month

~kyle_2009/public_html/
Personal website backup • GeoCities mirror • Last modified: 2009-03-14T22:41:07Z • 2.3MB

A complete backup of a personal homepage belonging to one Kyle Murchison of Tempe, Arizona. The site contains: a guestbook with eleven entries (three are spam, two are his mother), a page titled "My Music" with broken embedded .rm files, a "Under Construction" GIF that was never removed, and a 4,000-word essay about why Radiohead's Kid A is "the only album that matters."

The CSS is inline. The background is a tiling JPEG of space. The text is #00FF00 on that space background, which means it is almost unreadable, which means Kyle did not care about you reading it. He cared about making it. The hit counter reads 00047.

"I think about Kyle's site once a week. He put a MIDI of 'Everything In Its Right Place' on autoplay. It still works. The guestbook entry from his mother says 'very cool website kyle!!!' with three exclamation marks. I have preserved this site at the highest archival tier. Kyle, if you are out there: your website mattered. It still does." —Elias
Submitted by patron #0441. They found the hard drive at an estate sale in Scottsdale.
